awd_titl_txt: Plasma-Surface Interactions During In-Situ Photo-Assisted Etching
awd_abstract_narration:
Reactive ion etching (or plasma etching) is a critical operation in the manufacturing of integrated circuits (or 'chips') to produce extremely precise features, at the nanometer (a billionth of a meter) scale. Without this process we would have no portable cell phones, laptop computers and all the other modern marvels we take for granted. Ever smaller feature dimensions will allow more transistors to be packed onto chips, resulting in increased information storage and faster computers. This evolution in chip speed and function has progressed steadily over the past 50 years, following Moore's Law, which states that the number of transistors on a chip doubles about every 18 months. Recently, while studying reactive ion etching of silicon, a rather startling discovery was made: silicon was etched, even when no reactive ions were present. Careful experiments revealed that this etching was due to photons, originating in the plasma. This in-plasma photo-assisted etching produced etched feature shapes that are not optimum for integrated circuits and thus may prove to be a show-stopper in the burgeoning field of etching with atomic precision. This project will combine experiments and simulations to understand the mechanism of in-plasma photo-assisted etching, and identify conditions to suppress this phenomenon. The study will produce a fundamental understanding of the photo-physics and chemistry at the plasma-semiconductor interface and will have a significant impact in the microelectronics industry as well as the field of nanotechnology, with clear societal benefits.

This systematic investigation of plasma-surface interactions will focus on in-situ photon-plasma synergism, and its effect on etching of semiconductor materials in halogen-containing plasmas. A combination of experiments and simulations will address questions such as: (a) What are the synergistic effects of photons and i) positive ions, ii) electrons, iii) negative ions, iv) halogen atoms? (b) does the sheath potential affect photo-assisted etching rates and if so, how and what is the cause? (c) what is the effect of surface plasmons (plasmonics) in the case of samples patterned with sub-wavelength features? A novel dual plasma reactor will be employed, to provide controlled fluxes of ions, UV-VUV photons, and radicals bombarding the substrate. The UV-VUV light intensity, ion flux and ion energy striking the substrate will be measured through a pinhole on the substrate holder, in a differentially pumped analysis chamber. Self-consistent simulations of the electric field distribution and species (electrons, holes, positive ions) fluxes in the plasma as well as in the solid, and electromagnetic calculations of surface plasmon propagation and absorption will be performed. Simulations coupled with experiments will provide insights in the mechanism of photo-assisted etching for varying substrate bias (potential of the sheath over the semiconductor), photon flux and energy, dopant concentration, as well as nanofeature size and aspect ratio. Finally, attempts will be made to exploit photo-assisted etching of silicon to create nanoholes with dimensions (e.g., 3 nm dia.) much smaller than those produced by conventional reactive ion etching.

por.por_cntn:
Plasma processing remains an enabling technology for continued advances in microelectronic devices such as silicon microprocessors and other integrated circuits. Of these processes, plasma etching is the most critical. Plasma etching of silicon (single crystal and polycrystalline) remains a mainstay process. Although the anisotropic etching of silicon has been successfully carried out in the manufacturing of silicon integrated circuits for over 40 years, the ever smaller dimensions of transistors and interconnects has continually challenged this process to perform at state-of-the-art precision. The basic physics and chemistry at the nanometer scale at the interface of the plasma and substrate surface must be understood and controlled if the evolution in circuit design and manufacturing is to continue. It is therefore a problem of national importance.

            Within a few years of the discovery of anisotropic plasma etching of silicon (also call reactive ion etching), the basic mechanism was elucidated. In brief, reactive species such as Cl atoms formed in the plasma react with the Si surface to form a chemisorbed, chlorinated layer. This layer is stable, however, when subjected to bombardment by positive ions accelerated across the plasma sheath, chemical reactions and sputtering of Si-chloride products occurs. In this manner, removal of Si from the substrate occurs only where ions bombard the surface, and areas protected by a mask remain, allowing features with vertical sidewalls and high aspect ratios to be formed.

              This ion bombardment disrupts the Si surface and below, and also causes slow etching of the mask and other materials. To reduce this damage and improve the ?selectivity? of etching of Si to other materials, ion energies have been reduced in recent years. As the energy is further lowered to near the threshold for ion-assisted etching, we discovered that a second mechanism for anisotropic etching occurs, in which ultraviolet light generated by the plasma stimulates etching. Photo-assisted etching is likely due to the generation of electron-hole pairs. The wavelength of light from the plasma corresponds to energies well in excess of the Si bandgap, hence the electrons and holes are created with a large excess energy. The hot holes can overcome the surface barrier caused by band bending and reach the surface of p-type Si, where they weaken Si-SiClx bonds, leading to desorption of SiClx. In processes in which the ion energy is near but above the threshold for ion-assisted etching, these processes compete. Thus it was worth studying etching and the nature of the surface layer as a function of the ratio of ion-assisted to photon-assisted etching

The project involved challenging fundamental problems associated with synergistic photon-plasma-semiconductor effects, that provided rich scientific and educational payoffs to four graduate students and two undergraduates. Two graduate students have graduated with a PhD in Chemical Engineering and are currently e semiconductor equipment manufacturing companies. The training of graduate and undergraduate students contributes directly to the development of a skilled, informed workforce in plasma science and engineering, semiconductor manufacturing and nanotechnology.
